intro: Carex umbellata var. vicina, commonly known as the narrow-leaved sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to wetland and marshy environments in North America. It belongs to the Cyperaceae family and is characterized by its grass-like appearance with slender, cylindrical stems and narrow, grass-like leaves. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers arranged in spikes, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wet meadows, pond edges, and along stream banks. Due to its ecological importance, it plays a vital role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for various wildlife species.
